How global observation works in Federated Learning: Integrating vertical training into Horizontal Federated Learning

Shuo Wan, Jiaxun Lu,  Pingyi Fan,  Yunfeng Shao,  Chenghui Peng, and Khaled B. Letaief
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) has recently emerged as a transformative paradigm that jointly train a model with distributed data sets in IoT while avoiding the need for central data collection. Due to the limited observation range, such data sets can only reflect local information, which limits the quality of trained models. In practice, the global information and local observations would require a joint consideration for learning to make a reasonable policy. However, in horizontal FL, the central agency only acts as a model aggregator without utilizing its global observation to further improve the model. This could significantly degrade the performance in some missions such as traffic flow prediction in network systems, where the global information may enhance the accuracy. Meanwhile, the global feature may not be directly transmitted to agents for data security. How to utilize the global observation residing in the central agency while protecting its safety thus rises up as an important problem in FL. In this paper, we develop a vertical-horizontal federated learning (VHFL) process, where the global feature is shared with the agents in a procedure similar to that of vertical FL without any extra communication rounds. By considering the delay and packet loss, we will analyze VHFL convergence and validate its performance by experiments. It is shown that the proposed VHFL could enhance the accuracy compared with horizontal FL while still protecting the security of global data.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, Network system, Global feature, Collaborative training, Vertical-Horizontal FL.

I Introduction

Nowadays, big data is typically collected from distributed facilities or agents. Due to limitation on the network capacity and data security, however, it is hard to process data for central analysis. Therefore, distributed learning rises up as an important issue for data analysis in large-scale networks. In [1], the authors proposed Horizontal federated learning (HFL) which jointly trains a model among distributed clients through local training and model aggregation. In this process, the clients’ models are periodically trained based on previously aggregated models until convergence. Such a learning scheme allows applications to collectively reap the benefits of shared models trained from the rich data while avoiding the need of central data collection. That is, the trained FL model could assist the policy decision in IoT applications with a wider learned experience while protecting the security of the original agents.

Although the combined experience from distributed agents will largely improve the performance, it is still not enough if the global observation is not taken advantage of. Also and since the agents in IoT rarely work independently, correlations among them is unavoidable, which stresses the importance of global information in policy decision. For instance, the network trafic flow in one community will also affect its neighborhood. The self-driving performance may count on the positions and directions of neighboring cars. Such information typically resides in a central agency. Hence, if we can properly use such global observation in federated training, then the learned model will definitely give a better policy. Therefore, to improve FL for intelligent decisions among clients, how to utilize the global observation in the training procedure is a critical issue.

Integrating the global feature into horizontal FL faces many practical challenges in network system. Since the security may be threatened if the global observations are broadcast, the central agency often needs to keep its global data from being directly accessed by distributed clients. Therefore, the processing of global features should reside at the center. In this context and compared with conventional HFL, the central agency should announce its processed results other than just aggregating the model weights. Multiple challenging questions will thus need to be addressed. These include: How should we design such an FL mode to integrate a global processing? How can we jointly train the federated model and the global model with communication-efficient interactions? Does the joint training converges and what are the factors which can influence the convergence? In this paper, we will try to answer these important questions.

Vertical federated learning (VFL) [2, 3] is a modified scheme for cases in which the data sets share the same sample ID space but differ in the feature space. For instance, a commercial company and a bank may seperately record the related features of many users in a city. Combining these features in training will largely enhance the model accuracy. To deal with the security problem, VFL is designed to securely aggregate the varied features and compute the training loss and gradients to build a model with data from both companies collaboratively.

The training procedure of VFL provides a way to aggregate features from different agents. To integrate the global feature into HFL, the central agency could view the federal clients as another companion. In this sense, combining VFL into horizontal federated training provides a natural way for the central agency to share the global feature in security. It is known that the center in HFL only acts as a model aggregator. Under the concept of VFL, we will add a global model at the center to process the globally observed features. The processed results will be broadcast to distributed clients together with the aggregated model weights. When the local training is completed, the resulting loss for the global model will also be uploaded together with the updated weights of the local models. In this procedure, the extra transmissions are included in the periodic model aggregation and broadcast as in HFL. Since the processing results and feedback loss are rather small compared with the model weights, the system could naturally ensure communication efficiency. In this paper, we will propose a Vertical-Horizontal Federated Learning (VHFL) scheme and design the collaborative training procedure therein. Through theoretical analysis, we will prove its convergence considering the background packet loss and transmission delay in the networking system. Based on the network data among distributed communities, we will also test the convergence of VHFL and verify its performance. Hence, for IoT applications counting on global observations, it will be a practical scheme for distributed learning.

I-A Related works

Subsequent to the work in [1], FL has been widely investigated with improvement and further developments [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]. For vertically partitioned data in distributed clients, [2] introduced the VFL scheme with privacy preserving. In [3], the authors discussed the concept of federated transfer learning (FTL) for scenarios where two datasets differ both in the samples and feature spaces. This mode is specifically fit for scenarios where the united data sets among clients are very limited for FL. The training mode of FL is challenged by the heterogeneity among clients. Thus, in [4] and [5], the authors proposed the FedProx framework that allows each participating client to perform a variety amount of local training to achieve a more robust convergence. With the same aim, [6] tried to apply an adaptive optimizer on the model updates in FL. To cope with the non-i.i.d. data sets among clients, [7] presented clustered FL (CFL) which exploits the geometric properties of the FL loss surface to group the client population into clusters with jointly trainable data distributions. By counting on the client set for solution, [8] tried to maintain a control variate to correct the client-drift in its local updates. Among these works, [2, 3] tried to propose a new training mode for specific application scenarios while [4, 5, 6, 7, 8] tried to improve the original FedAvg for better convergence.

Since deploying distributed learning over wireless networks faces several challenges including the uncertain wireless environment, limited wireless resources and hardware resources [9], researchers discussed the facility basis of the platform [10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17]. In [10], the authors considered the capability of computing and model transmission and proposed a strategy to schedule the model uploading slots. In [11], the authors studied the delay in FL tasks and presented a unified framework to estimate the delay through fading channels. To relieve the transmission burden in FL, [12] proposed the sparse ternary compression (STC) framework to model transmission in FL and [13] considered training a binary neural network in FL. Considering the packet loss in wireless transmission, [14] analyzed the FL convergence with improved strategies for system scheduling. By analyzing the effects of hyper-parameters on FL convergence, [15] proposed theoretical design principles for FL implementation with the corresponding scheduling strategies. Considering large-scale FL, the authors of [16] proposed hierarchical FL with edge servers for intermediate aggregation and [17] discussed the edge association and resource allocation in this system.

I-B Contributions

In this paper, we focus on how to utilize the global observations in the central agency to assist FL on distributed data sets so that the learned model could achieve better performance. Our contributions can be summarized as follows.

  1. 1.

    We integrate the global observations into HFL and propose the Vertical-Horizontal Federated Learning (VHFL) scheme. We develop a collaborative training procedure with almost equivalent costs in communication compared with conventional HFL. In practice, it will be important for applications counting on the global information with security concern.

  2. 2.

    Through theoretical analysis, we prove the convergence of VHFL with analytic bounds and clearly demonstrates the effects of system parameters on training. By network analysis, we analyze the theoretical link between the network delay and transmission failure. Combined with the convergence bound, we also propose principles to set the delay due to network conditions and training requirements of VHFL. These results are expected to provide theoretical insights for the implementation of VHFL in future 6G networks.

  3. 3.

    We test VHFL on the measured data from a real network among communities and observe an improved accuracy in the prediction of network flow compared with HFL. It will be shown that for such applications among collaborative clients, the global information can significantly enhance the performance as clearly reflected by experiments.

II Vertical-Horizontal Federated Learning

We denote the feature space as X𝑋X, the label space as Y𝑌Y and the client sample ID space as I𝐼I. The client set is ℕ={1,2,…,N}ℕ12…𝑁\mathbb{N}=\{1,2,\dots,N\}. Therein, client j​(j∈N)𝑗𝑗𝑁j(j\in N) stores the data set 𝔻j=(Xj,Yj,Ij)subscript𝔻𝑗subscript𝑋𝑗subscript𝑌𝑗subscript𝐼𝑗\mathbb{D}_{j}=(X_{j},Y_{j},I_{j}), where Xjsubscript𝑋𝑗X_{j} and Yjsubscript𝑌𝑗Y_{j} are the feature space and label space of client j𝑗j and Ijsubscript𝐼𝑗I_{j} with |Ij|=Djsubscript𝐼𝑗subscript𝐷𝑗|I_{j}|=D_{j} is the index set of samples in client j𝑗j. Denoting the model weight as w𝑤w, then the training loss of client j𝑗j is

fj​(w)=1Dj​∑m=1Djl​(w,(xim,yim)),subscript𝑓𝑗𝑤1subscript𝐷𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑚1subscript𝐷𝑗𝑙𝑤subscript𝑥subscript𝑖𝑚subscript𝑦subscript𝑖𝑚f_{j}(w)=\frac{1}{D_{j}}\sum_{m=1}^{D_{j}}l(w,(x_{i_{m}},y_{i_{m}})), (1)

where im∈Ijsubscript𝑖𝑚subscript𝐼𝑗i_{m}\in I_{j} is the sample index of client j𝑗j and l​(⋅,⋅)𝑙⋅⋅l(\cdot,\cdot) is the loss function. In this section, we will first introduce the system model and background learning techniques. Then we will specifically discuss the training procedure of VHFL in detail.

II-A Problem formulation and System model

In this paper, we consider a collaborative learning system as shown in Fig. 1. In the network system, the intelligent clients ℕ={1,2,…,N}ℕ12…𝑁\mathbb{N}=\{1,2,\dots,N\} reside in distributed regions, each with its own data set 𝔻j=(Xj,Yj,Ij)subscript𝔻𝑗subscript𝑋𝑗subscript𝑌𝑗subscript𝐼𝑗\mathbb{D}_{j}=(X_{j},Y_{j},I_{j}) from local observations. The central agency should be a network center which stores the synthesized information. The global data set at the center is denoted as 𝔻0=(X0,I0)subscript𝔻0subscript𝑋0subscript𝐼0\mathbb{D}_{0}=(X_{0},I_{0}). Sometimes, if the global observations are obtained generally not corresponding to the specific sampling ID, the global data will only involve the observing features in the form 𝔻0=(X0)subscript𝔻0subscript𝑋0\mathbb{D}_{0}=(X_{0}), which can be viewed as a special case.

Assuming that the clients intend to train a model for policy making in local applications, then they will need the combined experience from other clients and the central agency. Samples of other clients could enrich the model training with improved accuracy. Meanwhile, the global feature contains observations of the whole system, which is often crucial for policy decisions. Here comes the major problem. Hence how the clients and central agency could train a model collaboratively without transmitting their data sets is a critical question. Other questions include: Could the training ensure a convergence in the network system? Considering the network connection, how should we implement the joint training considering unreliable communication?

As shown in Fig. 1, the central agency and clients are connected through the network, which can be wireless or wired. Each client trains the model locally and the center also maintains a global model to process the central set 𝔻0subscript𝔻0\mathbb{D}_{0}. The center and local agents interact periodically for model aggregation and vertical training.

Note that it is not realistic for the network to specifically support the learning system. All services should go through a public network for communication. Considering the random arriving rate and transmission rate naturally existing in the public network, the communication between a client and a central agency should be modeled as a queuing system. In this paper, we will analyze the delay and packet loss of VHFL considering an M/G/1 queuing network. The packet arriving rate is λNsubscript𝜆𝑁\lambda_{N}, which can be measured by experiment. The transmission rate depends on the network conditions. During busy periods, the network is rather congested while the service at casual preriods can be much higher. This is a very natural property of the public network which can be modeled by a 2-stage hyper-exponential distribution. Therein, the probability distribution of the service time can be given by

B​(t)=α1​μ1​e−μ1​t+α2​μ2​e−μ2​t,𝐵𝑡subscript𝛼1subscript𝜇1superscript𝑒subscript𝜇1𝑡subscript𝛼2subscript𝜇2superscript𝑒subscript𝜇2𝑡B(t)=\alpha_{1}\mu_{1}e^{-\mu_{1}t}+\alpha_{2}\mu_{2}e^{-\mu_{2}t}, (2)

where μ1subscript𝜇1\mu_{1}, μ2subscript𝜇2\mu_{2} are seperately the service rate at the idle and busy states (μ1>μ2subscript𝜇1subscript𝜇2\mu_{1}>\mu_{2}) and α1subscript𝛼1\alpha_{1}, α2subscript𝛼2\alpha_{2} are the probability weights of the two states. These parameters can be directly measured from the practical flow records in the network for guidence.

In HFL or VHFL, the center will collect messages from clients for central training or weight aggregation. Thus, the varied delays will be an important factor to disturb the central collection. In practical operations, the center will set a deadline and any uploading beyond the deadline will be lost. Note that the TCP will retransmit lost packets as a result of congestion. From the view of the central collector, this is equivalent to a larger delay modeled by the congested rate μ2subscript𝜇2\mu_{2}. Therefore, the packet loss due to time out could cover most cases in the network. In this paper, we will analyze the uploading delay to guide the system design for VHFL implementation.

II-B Background technique: Federated Learning

II-B1 Horizontal FL (HFL)

The HFL system involves a center and a set of clients ℕℕ\mathbb{N}. For an arbitrary client i𝑖i and j𝑗j (i≠j)𝑖𝑗(i\neq j), the stored data sets satify Xi=Xjsubscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑋𝑗X_{i}=X_{j}, Yi=Yjsubscript𝑌𝑖subscript𝑌𝑗Y_{i}=Y_{j} and Ii≠Ijsubscript𝐼𝑖subscript𝐼𝑗I_{i}\neq I_{j}. That is, the clients in HFL share the same space for their features and labels in a common training task. However, due to different positions, the sampling ID naturally varies among the clients. Thus, HFL must share the sample sets with varied ID spaces to train a general model by local training and model aggregation. Given the local loss function, fj​(w)subscript𝑓𝑗𝑤f_{j}(w), as defined in (1) and qjsubscript𝑞𝑗q_{j} as the weight of client j𝑗j, the training loss of HFL is defined as

f​(w)=∑j=1Nqj​fj​(w).𝑓𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑗subscript𝑓𝑗𝑤f(w)=\sum_{j=1}^{N}q_{j}f_{j}(w). (3)

The training process is done periodically with Elsubscript𝐸𝑙E_{l} as the period length. Defining t𝑡t as an arbitrary training slot, tc=⌊tEl⌋​Elsubscript𝑡𝑐𝑡subscript𝐸𝑙subscript𝐸𝑙t_{c}=\left\lfloor\frac{t}{E_{l}}\right\rfloor E_{l} is the start slot of the current global epoch. At tcsubscript𝑡𝑐t_{c}, clients download the updated model w¯tcsuperscript¯𝑤subscript𝑡𝑐\bar{w}^{t_{c}} to initialize the upcoming local training. Then at t≠tc𝑡subscript𝑡𝑐t\neq t_{c}, each client is trained locally as

wjtc+i+1=wjtc+i−ηtc+i▽fj​(wjtc+i),superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑗subscript𝑡𝑐𝑖1▽superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑗subscript𝑡𝑐𝑖superscript𝜂subscript𝑡𝑐𝑖subscript𝑓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑗subscript𝑡𝑐𝑖w_{j}^{t_{c}+i+1}=w_{j}^{t_{c}+i}-\eta^{t_{c}+i}\bigtriangledown f_{j}(w_{j}^{t_{c}+i}), (4)

where wjtsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑗𝑡w_{j}^{t} is the local model weight of client j𝑗j at slot t𝑡t and ηtsuperscript𝜂𝑡\eta^{t} is the learning rate. The stochastic gradient decent in (4) can be varied with other optimizers, following the same procedure. After Elsubscript𝐸𝑙E_{l} epochs of local training, a client set ℙℙ\mathbb{P} (|ℙ|=Kℙ𝐾|\mathbb{P}|=K, K≤N𝐾𝑁K\leq N) out of ℕℕ\mathbb{N} will be selected to upload the locally trained model for aggregation at the center. Upon receiving the models, the central agency will update the federal model weight as

w¯t=NK​∑j∈ℙqj​wjt,superscript¯𝑤𝑡𝑁𝐾subscript𝑗ℙsubscript𝑞𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑗𝑡\bar{w}^{t}=\frac{N}{K}\sum_{j\in\mathbb{P}}q_{j}w_{j}^{t}, (5)

where E​[NK​∑j∈ℙqj]=1𝐸delimited-[]𝑁𝐾subscript𝑗ℙsubscript𝑞𝑗1E[\frac{N}{K}\sum_{j\in\mathbb{P}}q_{j}]=1. Then w¯tsuperscript¯𝑤𝑡\bar{w}^{t} will be downloaded by clients to initialize the local training in the next global epoch. Such HFL learning procedure requires clients to share the same space in feature and label so that they could train on the same model structure. By aggregation, the models trained by distributed sampling sets could be combined as the federal model with the experience of all the clients. Its convergence has been proved by experiments and theoretical analysis [1, 15].

II-B2 Vertical FL (VFL)

In some cases, two agents may share the same sample space (IA=IBsubscript𝐼𝐴subscript𝐼𝐵I_{A}=I_{B}) but differ in the feature spaces (XA≠XBsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑋𝐵X_{A}\neq X_{B}) [3]. For instance, a bank A𝐴A and an e-commerce company B𝐵B may share the same user set containing most residents of a particular location. However, due to the difference in their business, the two companies naturally record different features of a user. Suppose that two agents want to have a prediction model of product purchases based on the recorded features in both data bases, then VFL will satisfy the requirement while avoiding the need of data collection.

In VFL, we have XA≠XBsubscript𝑋𝐴subscript𝑋𝐵X_{A}\neq X_{B}, YA≠YBsubscript𝑌𝐴subscript𝑌𝐵Y_{A}\neq Y_{B} and IA=IBsubscript𝐼𝐴subscript𝐼𝐵I_{A}=I_{B}. Let us suppose company B𝐵B contains labels for the prediction task. Thus, the data sets of both companies are {xiA}superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐴\{x_{i}^{A}\} and {xiB,yi}superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐵subscript𝑦𝑖\{x_{i}^{B},y_{i}\}. Denoting the model weight as wAsubscript𝑤𝐴w_{A} and wBsubscript𝑤𝐵w_{B}, and the learning rate as η𝜂\eta, then the training objective is

minwA,wB​f​(wA,wB)=minwA,wB​∑iL​((wA,xiA),(wB,xiB),yi),subscript𝑤𝐴subscript𝑤𝐵min𝑓subscript𝑤𝐴subscript𝑤𝐵subscript𝑤𝐴subscript𝑤𝐵minsubscript𝑖𝐿subscript𝑤𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐴subscript𝑤𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐵subscript𝑦𝑖\underset{w_{A},w_{B}}{{\rm min}}f(w_{A},w_{B})=\underset{w_{A},w_{B}}{{\rm min}}\sum_{i}L((w_{A},x_{i}^{A}),(w_{B},x_{i}^{B}),y_{i}), (6)

where L​((wA,xiA),(wB,xiB),yi)𝐿subscript𝑤𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐴subscript𝑤𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐵subscript𝑦𝑖L((w_{A},x_{i}^{A}),(w_{B},x_{i}^{B}),y_{i}) is the vertical model loss with joint feature processing of sample i𝑖i. Since the label is stored in company B𝐵B, the model in A𝐴A will process xiAsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐴x_{i}^{A} and output uiA=hwA​(xiA)superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝐴subscriptℎsubscript𝑤𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐴u_{i}^{A}=h_{w_{A}}(x_{i}^{A}) to model B𝐵B. Then model B𝐵B will take uiAsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝐴u_{i}^{A} and xiBsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐵x_{i}^{B} as input to obtain the prediction result as uiB=hwB​(uiA,xiB)superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝐵subscriptℎsubscript𝑤𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐵u_{i}^{B}=h_{w_{B}}(u_{i}^{A},x_{i}^{B}). By taking the Mean Square Error (MSE) loss as an example, then the loss function in (6) can be given as

L​((wA,xiA),(wB,xiB),yi)=‖hwB​(hwA​(xiA),xiB)−yi‖2.𝐿subscript𝑤𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐴subscript𝑤𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐵subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptnormsubscriptℎsubscript𝑤𝐵subscriptℎsubscript𝑤𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐵subscript𝑦𝑖2L((w_{A},x_{i}^{A}),(w_{B},x_{i}^{B}),y_{i})=||h_{w_{B}}(h_{w_{A}}(x_{i}^{A}),x_{i}^{B})-y_{i}||^{2}. (7)

For neural networks, model B𝐵B could process xiBsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐵x_{i}^{B} with the former layers and the abstracted result could be combined with uiAsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝐴u_{i}^{A} to get the prediction result through the final dense layers. For simplicity, we can also process xiBsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝐵x_{i}^{B} with model B𝐵B to get uiBsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝐵u_{i}^{B} and take uiA+uiBsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝐵u_{i}^{A}+u_{i}^{B} as the prediction result [3], which is actually a special case of (7). In the training procedure, wBsubscript𝑤𝐵w_{B} is updated by

wBt+1=wBt−ηt▽wBf​(wA,wB).superscriptsubscript𝑤𝐵𝑡1subscript▽subscript𝑤𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑤𝐵𝑡superscript𝜂𝑡𝑓subscript𝑤𝐴subscript𝑤𝐵w_{B}^{t+1}=w_{B}^{t}-\eta^{t}\bigtriangledown_{w_{B}}f(w_{A},w_{B}). (8)

Meanwhile, model A𝐴A will receive ▽uAf​(wA,wB)subscript▽superscript𝑢𝐴𝑓subscript𝑤𝐴subscript𝑤𝐵\bigtriangledown_{u^{A}}f(w_{A},w_{B}) for the samples and update wAsubscript𝑤𝐴w_{A} as

wAt+1=wAt−ηt▽wA▽uAf(wA,wB).w_{A}^{t+1}=w_{A}^{t}-\eta^{t}\bigtriangledown_{w_{A}}\bigtriangledown_{u^{A}}f(w_{A},w_{B}). (9)

In terms of neural network implementation, model A𝐴A will send the output uAsuperscript𝑢𝐴u^{A} to model B𝐵B and receive the gradient ▽uAfsubscript▽superscript𝑢𝐴𝑓\bigtriangledown_{u^{A}}f to update wAsubscript𝑤𝐴w_{A} in the backward mode. For security concern, VFL will also apply encryption in transmission and follows the same procedure.

II-C Vertical-Horizontal FL (VHFL)

Due to concern of data privacy and communication burden, an arbitrary client i𝑖i will not share the local set 𝔻isubscript𝔻𝑖\mathbb{D}_{i} for central training. Meanwhile, the global observations typically contain sensitive information of the whole system. Spreading the global data around clients could seriously threaten the security. Thus, the center will also train a model to process the global information and share the results with clients for prediction. In VHFL, the clients will jointly train in the HFL mode. In this process, the center will not only aggregate the model weights as in HFL, but also train its own global model to assist the HFL among clients with global information. In Section II-B, we have discussed the training procedure of HFL and VFL. Here, we will introduce how these modes are combined for collaborative training in VHFL while avoiding the transmission of raw data.

The data flow and interaction mode in VHFL is shown in Fig. 2. The center maintains a global model with weight w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} to process the global features. The distributed clients train the local models {wj|j∈1,2,…,N}conditional-setsubscript𝑤𝑗𝑗12…𝑁\{w_{j}|j\in{1,2,\dots,N}\} for processing of local features. As in HFL, the center will choose K𝐾K clients to upload the local weight at each global epoch. The aggregated weights will be transmitted to all clients for processing of their local features. Thus, the federal weight for processing local features is

w¯t=NK​∑j∈ℙqj​wjt,superscript¯𝑤𝑡𝑁𝐾subscript𝑗ℙsubscript𝑞𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑗𝑡\bar{w}^{t}=\frac{N}{K}\sum_{j\in\mathbb{P}}q_{j}w_{j}^{t}, (10)

which is similar to (5) in HFL. Here, the center processes the central data 𝔻0subscript𝔻0\mathbb{D}_{0} with model w0subscript𝑤0w_{0}. w0tc+El=w0tc−η0tc∑j∈ℙ▽w0▽u0fj(w0,wj),w_{0}^{t_{c}+E_{l}}=w_{0}^{t_{c}}-\eta_{0}^{t_{c}}\sum_{j\in\mathbb{P}}\bigtriangledown_{w_{0}}\bigtriangledown_{u^{0}}f_{j}(w_{0},w_{j}), (17)

where η0tcsuperscriptsubscript𝜂0subscript𝑡𝑐\eta_{0}^{t_{c}} is the learning rate for central training. Note that the central operation only occurs at the end of each global epoch, which means (17) is performed every Elsubscript𝐸𝑙E_{l} slots. After training, the renewed {ul0}superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑙0\{u_{l}^{0}\} will be downloaded together with the aggregated w¯¯𝑤\bar{w}. The local training of the next global epoch then begins. The training procedure is supposed to end when the loss converges.

The trained model can assist the local applications among clients such as predicting for policy decision. In the inference procedure, the global model will apply the trained w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} to process the corresponding global observations. The local model will apply the trained federal weights w¯¯𝑤\bar{w} to process the local observations and central output with the final results. Note that the central observations typically reflect the states of the whole system. They are rather stable and will not change in a period. Therefore, the central agency could process the related central observations for a client in a period without frequent interactions. This ensures the flexibility of the local applications.

III Convergence Analysis

In Section II-C, we have discussed the training procedure of VHFL in detail. In this section, considering the non-i.i.d. data distribution among clients, we will analyze the convergence of VHFL in the convex and non-convex cases. Beforehand, the basic assumptions from the literature and the non-i.i.d. metric for data distribution will be first introduced. Then the convergence bound will be derived and discussed in detail.

III-A Basic assumptions

III-A1 Assumptions on loss function

The assumptions on L-smooth for smoothness and μ𝜇\mu-Polyak-Lojasiewicz (PL) conditions for model convexity are given as follows.

Assumption 1

(L-smooth) The loss function f(.)f(.) satisfies

f​(y→)≤f​(x→)+(y→−x→)T▽f​(x→)+L2​‖y→−x→‖2,𝑓→𝑦▽𝑓→𝑥superscript→𝑦→𝑥𝑇𝑓→𝑥𝐿2superscriptnorm→𝑦→𝑥2\displaystyle f(\overrightarrow{y})\leq f(\overrightarrow{x})+(\overrightarrow{y}-\overrightarrow{x})^{T}\bigtriangledown f(\overrightarrow{x})+\frac{L}{2}\left\|\overrightarrow{y}-\overrightarrow{x}\right\|^{2}, (18)

where x→→𝑥\overrightarrow{x} and y→→𝑦\overrightarrow{y} represent a combination of multiple parameters.

Assumption 2

(μ𝜇\mu-P-L condition) The loss function f(.)f(.) in FL training satisfies the following general extension of the μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex property

‖▽f​(x→)‖2≥2​μ​[f​(x→)−f∗],superscriptnorm▽𝑓→𝑥22𝜇delimited-[]𝑓→𝑥superscript𝑓\displaystyle||\bigtriangledown f(\overrightarrow{x})||^{2}\geq 2\mu[f(\overrightarrow{x})-f^{*}], (19)

where f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} is the optimal loss.

Remark 1

In analysis of non-convex cases, we will only take Assumption 1, while Assumption 2 will only be considered for the convex cases. Note that if viewing f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} as the local optimum, the assumption could still work for non-convex models. Therefore, the convergence bound for convex cases can still fit for models such as neural networks.

III-A2 Non-i.i.d. metric

Due to different local environments, the local observations among clients can be varied in probability distributions. Such a property can largely affect the convergence, which must be considered with the metric in the analytic form.

Definition 1

[18, 19] Given client set ℕℕ\mathbb{N} with weights {qj}subscript𝑞𝑗\{q_{j}\} and {▽fj​(w0,wj)}▽subscript𝑓𝑗subscript𝑤0subscript𝑤𝑗\{\bigtriangledown f_{j}(w_{0},w_{j})\} as their gradients, the metric λ𝜆\lambda for non-i.i.d. extent is defined as

∑j=1Nqj​‖▽fj​(w0,wj)‖2‖∑j=1Nqj▽fj​(w0,wj)‖2=∧≤λ.\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{N}q_{j}\left\|\bigtriangledown f_{j}(w_{0},w_{j})\right\|^{2}}{\left\|\sum_{j=1}^{N}q_{j}\bigtriangledown f_{j}(w_{0},w_{j})\right\|^{2}}=\wedge\leq\lambda. (20)
Remark 2

It is obvious to see that λ≥1𝜆1\lambda\geq 1. Under such metric, λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1 represents the i.i.d. case. The metric λ𝜆\lambda reflects the divergence of the stochastic gradients among the clients.

III-B Convergence bound

Theorem 1

Denoting the learning rate as ηt∝O​(1t)proportional-tosubscript𝜂𝑡𝑂1𝑡\eta_{t}\propto O(\frac{1}{t}), the total number of global epochs as Tg=⌊tEl⌋subscript𝑇𝑔𝑡subscript𝐸𝑙T_{g}=\left\lfloor\frac{t}{E_{l}}\right\rfloor and an arbitrary global epoch as tgsubscript𝑡𝑔t_{g} (tg≤Tgsubscript𝑡𝑔subscript𝑇𝑔t_{g}\leq T_{g}), then under Assumption 1 and Definition 1, the VHFL training in the non-convex case converges as

1Tg​∑tg=0Tg−1‖▽f​(w¯tg,w0tg)‖2≤2​f​(w¯0,w00)−f∗Tg​El1subscript𝑇𝑔superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑡𝑔0subscript𝑇𝑔1superscriptnorm▽𝑓superscript¯𝑤subscript𝑡𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑤0subscript𝑡𝑔22𝑓superscript¯𝑤0superscriptsubscript𝑤00superscript𝑓subscript𝑇𝑔subscript𝐸𝑙\displaystyle\frac{1}{T_{g}}\sum_{t_{g}=0}^{T_{g}-1}||\bigtriangledown f(\bar{w}^{t_{g}},w_{0}^{t_{g}})||^{2}\leq 2\frac{f(\bar{w}^{0},w_{0}^{0})-f^{*}}{\sqrt{T_{g}}\sqrt{E_{l}}}
+L​ElTg​[El​σ02+σ2K​(1El+(λ−1)​L)+(λ−1)​L​El​G2].𝐿subscript𝐸𝑙subscript𝑇𝑔delimited-[]subscript𝐸𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜎02superscript𝜎2𝐾1subscript𝐸𝑙𝜆1𝐿𝜆1𝐿subscript𝐸𝑙superscript𝐺2\displaystyle+\frac{L\sqrt{E_{l}}}{\sqrt{T_{g}}}[E_{l}\sigma_{0}^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{K}(\frac{1}{E_{l}}+(\lambda-1)L)+(\lambda-1)LE_{l}G^{2}]. (21)

Further considering Assumption 2, then the convergence bound of VHFL in the convex case is

E​[F​(w0tg,w¯tg)]−f∗≤1Tg​2​Lμ2𝐸delimited-[]𝐹superscriptsubscript𝑤0subscript𝑡𝑔superscript¯𝑤subscript𝑡𝑔superscript𝑓1subscript𝑇𝑔2𝐿superscript𝜇2\displaystyle E[F(w_{0}^{t_{g}},\bar{w}^{t_{g}})]-f^{*}\leq\frac{1}{T_{g}}\frac{2L}{\mu^{2}}

(22)

Therein, the gradient ‖▽f​(w¯tg,w0tg)‖2superscriptnorm▽𝑓superscript¯𝑤subscript𝑡𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑤0subscript𝑡𝑔2||\bigtriangledown f(\bar{w}^{t_{g}},w_{0}^{t_{g}})||^{2} is short for ‖▽w¯f​(w¯tg,w0tg)‖2+‖▽w0f​(w¯tg,w0tg)‖2superscriptnormsubscript▽¯𝑤𝑓superscript¯𝑤subscript𝑡𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑤0subscript𝑡𝑔2superscriptnormsubscript▽subscript𝑤0𝑓superscript¯𝑤subscript𝑡𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑤0subscript𝑡𝑔2||\bigtriangledown_{\bar{w}}f(\bar{w}^{t_{g}},w_{0}^{t_{g}})||^{2}+||\bigtriangledown_{w_{0}}f(\bar{w}^{t_{g}},w_{0}^{t_{g}})||^{2} and f0subscript𝑓0f_{0} is proportional to ▽f​(w¯0,w00)▽𝑓superscript¯𝑤0superscriptsubscript𝑤00\bigtriangledown f(\bar{w}^{0},w_{0}^{0}). The corner mark represents the gradient at the tgsubscript𝑡𝑔t_{g}-th global epoch and f​(w¯0,w00)𝑓superscript¯𝑤0superscriptsubscript𝑤00f(\bar{w}^{0},w_{0}^{0}) is the initial loss. The parameter G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} is the gradient upper bound and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, σ02superscriptsubscript𝜎02\sigma_{0}^{2} are the stochastic gradient variance of ▽w¯fsubscript▽¯𝑤𝑓\bigtriangledown_{\bar{w}}f, ▽w0fsubscript▽subscript𝑤0𝑓\bigtriangledown_{w_{0}}f. The proof is shown in Appendix A.

In the non-convex case, the bound (1) indicates that the gradients of VHFL converges at the rate O​(1Tg)𝑂1subscript𝑇𝑔O(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T_{g}}}). As known, the back proporgation can only ensure that the local optimization problem in non-convex. As the gradients approaches 00, the result will surely reach a stationary point, which can be viewed as a solution in the non-convex case. In fact, the training of deep neural networks is typically a non-convex case. However, we could ensure the accuracy using methods such as random initialization, enlarging data samples, etc.

In the convex case, the bound (1) shows that the loss function converges towards the global optimum at the rate O​(1Tg)𝑂1subscript𝑇𝑔O(\frac{1}{T_{g}}). The optimization of the convex problem is rather simple with a single stationary point, which leads to a direct bound with respect to f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}. In the training of deep neural networks, f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} can be viewed as a local optimum. Thus, such bound still maintains its effectiveness to assist the design.

The hyper-parameters in the background system can largely affect the convergence speed as shown in (1) and (1). Therein, more collected models in each global epoch results in a larger K𝐾K. Thus, the errors from the non-i.i.d. distribution (λ𝜆\lambda) and stochastic variance (σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}) can be naturally reduced. A larger local epoch leads to more sufficient training on the local data sets, which enhances the overall convergence speed. However, in cases with a high non-i.i.d. distribution (λ𝜆\lambda) or large stochastic variance (σ02superscriptsubscript𝜎02\sigma_{0}^{2}) in the global set, the performance can be worse. Note that the non-i.i.d. distribution could largely affect the convergence. In some extreme cases, λ𝜆\lambda can even approach infinity, which will definitely lead to the failure of convergence. Thus, we should try to reduce the non-i.i.d. distribution in practice. A common operation is to distribute some public data among clients, so that the uploaded models can enjoy a larger similarity in general.

Compared with HFL, VHFL introduces an additional central stochastic variance (σ02superscriptsubscript𝜎02\sigma_{0}^{2}). From Theorem 1, increasing Elsubscript𝐸𝑙E_{l} will enlarge the effects of σ02superscriptsubscript𝜎02\sigma_{0}^{2}. From the view of central training, too much local training may cause large asynchronism and enlarge the variance from the central data sets. In this case, the theorem is fitted with common sense. From an implementation perspective, we can enrich the central set to reduce σ02superscriptsubscript𝜎02\sigma_{0}^{2}. Then VHFL could guarantee a similar convergence rate as the general HFL training.

IV Network analysis for VHFL implementation

The joint training of the central agency and distributed clients counts on interactions among the global model and local models. However, due to the random flow burden and link conditions, the network is typically unreliable. For services of VHFL, the packet loss and delay in network transmission will degrade the model aggregation. Note that the TCP will retransmit the lost packets, which results in a larger delay. In this case, the packet loss condition can be covered by increasing the network delay. To cope with the unknown transmission time, the central agency will set an upper-bound for delay as Tpsubscript𝑇𝑝T_{p}. Any packet arriving latter than Tpsubscript𝑇𝑝T_{p} will be lost. Denoting the average success rate of packet transmission as γ𝛾\gamma, then the network will actually collect Kγ=K​γsubscript𝐾𝛾𝐾𝛾K_{\gamma}=K\gamma models in each global epoch. Thus, the parameter K𝐾K in Theorem 1 should be modified as Kγ=K​γsubscript𝐾𝛾𝐾𝛾K_{\gamma}=K\gamma. Then (1) for the non-convex cases should be modified as

1Tg​∑tg=0Tg−1‖▽f​(w¯tg,w0tg)‖2≤2​f​(w¯0,w00)−f∗Tg​El1subscript𝑇𝑔superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑡𝑔0subscript𝑇𝑔1superscriptnorm▽𝑓superscript¯𝑤subscript𝑡𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑤0subscript𝑡𝑔22𝑓superscript¯𝑤0superscriptsubscript𝑤00superscript𝑓subscript𝑇𝑔subscript𝐸𝑙\displaystyle\frac{1}{T_{g}}\sum_{t_{g}=0}^{T_{g}-1}||\bigtriangledown f(\bar{w}^{t_{g}},w_{0}^{t_{g}})||^{2}\leq 2\frac{f(\bar{w}^{0},w_{0}^{0})-f^{*}}{\sqrt{T_{g}}\sqrt{E_{l}}}
+L​ElTg​[El​σ02+σ2K​γ​(1El+(λ−1)​L)+(λ−1)​L​El​G2].𝐿subscript𝐸𝑙subscript𝑇𝑔delimited-[]subscript𝐸𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜎02superscript𝜎2𝐾𝛾1subscript𝐸𝑙𝜆1𝐿𝜆1𝐿subscript𝐸𝑙superscript𝐺2\displaystyle+\frac{L\sqrt{E_{l}}}{\sqrt{T_{g}}}[E_{l}\sigma_{0}^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{K\gamma}(\frac{1}{E_{l}}+(\lambda-1)L)+(\lambda-1)LE_{l}G^{2}]. (23)

The bound (1) for the convex cases will be

E[f(w0tg,w¯tg)]−f∗=1Tg2​Lμ2[Elσ02\displaystyle E[f(w_{0}^{t_{g}},\bar{w}^{t_{g}})]-f^{*}=\frac{1}{T_{g}}\frac{2L}{\mu^{2}}[E_{l}\sigma_{0}^{2}
+σ2K​γ(1El+(λ−1)L)+(λ−1)LElG2+f0​G24​El].\displaystyle+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{K\gamma}(\frac{1}{E_{l}}+(\lambda-1)L)+(\lambda-1)LE_{l}G^{2}+\frac{f_{0}G^{2}}{4E_{l}}]. (24)

The convergence of VHFL in practical networks can be described in (IV) and (IV), where the model aggregator can suffer from the network loss due to the diminished K𝐾K. Therefore, we should be able to control γ𝛾\gamma so that the aggregated amount K𝐾K can be guaranteed for VHFL in practical networks. As stated in Section II-A, the network delay is modeled as an M/G/1𝑀𝐺1M/G/1 queuing system. In this section, considering the delay upper-bound Tpsubscript𝑇𝑝T_{p}, we will give an analysis of γ𝛾\gamma for VHFL implementation. We will then answer how we should assign the communication module considering the requirements of VHFL training.

The network transmission rate is composed of μ1subscript𝜇1\mu_{1} (idle states) and μ2subscript𝜇2\mu_{2} (busy states). In practice, the arriving rate λNsubscript𝜆𝑁\lambda_{N} and α1subscript𝛼1\alpha_{1}, α2subscript𝛼2\alpha_{2}, μ1subscript𝜇1\mu_{1}, μ2subscript𝜇2\mu_{2} in (2) can be measured from the public network with an estimated value. Then an analysis of γ𝛾\gamma can be obtained using the following theorem.

Theorem 2

Assuming the network transmission between an arbitrary client and the center is an M/G/1𝑀𝐺1M/G/1 process, where λNsubscript𝜆𝑁\lambda_{N}, α1subscript𝛼1\alpha_{1}, α2subscript𝛼2\alpha_{2}, μ1subscript𝜇1\mu_{1}, μ2subscript𝜇2\mu_{2} can be measured from the network. If the delay upper-bound in VHFL for aggregation is set as Tpsubscript𝑇𝑝T_{p}, then the success rate γ𝛾\gamma is

γ=1𝛾1\displaystyle\gamma=1 +(1−ρ)​(μ1,2​s1+μ1​μ2)(s1−s2)​s1​es1​Tp1𝜌subscript𝜇12subscript𝑠1subscript𝜇1subscript𝜇2subscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2subscript𝑠1superscript𝑒subscript𝑠1subscript𝑇𝑝\displaystyle+\frac{(1-\rho)(\mu_{1,2}s_{1}+\mu_{1}\mu_{2})}{(s_{1}-s_{2})s_{1}}e^{s_{1}T_{p}}
−(1−ρ)​(μ1,2​s2+μ1​μ2)(s1−s2)​s2​es2​Tp,1𝜌subscript𝜇12subscript𝑠2subscript𝜇1subscript𝜇2subscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2subscript𝑠2superscript𝑒subscript𝑠2subscript𝑇𝑝\displaystyle-\frac{(1-\rho)(\mu_{1,2}s_{2}+\mu_{1}\mu_{2})}{(s_{1}-s_{2})s_{2}}e^{s_{2}T_{p}}, (25)

where μ1,2=α1​μ1+α2​μ2subscript𝜇12subscript𝛼1subscript𝜇1subscript𝛼2subscript𝜇2\mu_{1,2}=\alpha_{1}\mu_{1}+\alpha_{2}\mu_{2} and ρ=α1​λNμ1+α2​λNμ2𝜌subscript𝛼1subscript𝜆𝑁subscript𝜇1subscript𝛼2subscript𝜆𝑁subscript𝜇2\rho=\alpha_{1}\frac{\lambda_{N}}{\mu_{1}}+\alpha_{2}\frac{\lambda_{N}}{\mu_{2}}. s1subscript𝑠1s_{1} and s2subscript𝑠2s_{2} are given as

s1,2=12[(λN−μ1−μ2)+¯\displaystyle s_{1,2}=\frac{1}{2}[(\lambda_{N}-\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})\underline{+}
μ12+μ22+λN2−2​μ1​μ2+2​λN​μ1+2​λN​μ2−4​μ1,2​λN].\displaystyle\sqrt{\mu_{1}^{2}+\mu_{2}^{2}+\lambda_{N}^{2}-2\mu_{1}\mu_{2}+2\lambda_{N}\mu_{1}+2\lambda_{N}\mu_{2}-4\mu_{1,2}\lambda_{N}}]. (26)

The proof is provided in Appendix B.

Theorem 2 provides a method to estimate the failure rate in model aggregations due to network conditions and delay setting. From Theorem 1, the training convergence improves with K𝐾K in an inversely proportional manner. Then if K𝐾K is not large enough, the training can be seriously affected. In practice, we can obtain an appropriate K𝐾K from experience so that VHFL can gain reasonable convergence. Then by facing such unreliable network, how can we ensure that we can actually achieve K𝐾K?

The scheduling of VHFL communication links through the public internet is summarized in Fig. 3. Assume that the network permits K0subscript𝐾0K_{0} clients to upload models due to the scheduled capability for VHFL communication, we should ensure γ≥KK0𝛾𝐾subscript𝐾0\gamma\geq\frac{K}{K_{0}} to guarantee the training convergence. In public networks, the transmission rate can be estimated by existing flow data by experience. By setting γ=KK0𝛾𝐾subscript𝐾0\gamma=\frac{K}{K_{0}}, we could solve (2) by bisection search to get Tpsubscript𝑇𝑝T_{p}. For model aggregation in VHFL, we could let the central trainer wait for time Tpsubscript𝑇𝑝T_{p} to collect distributed feedback before training. Here, Tpsubscript𝑇𝑝T_{p} is a guide from theoretical model. The practical system may perform slight adjustment around Tpsubscript𝑇𝑝T_{p} through experiments.

V Experiments

V-A Basic settings

We test the VHFL on the flow data in a practical network among a range of communities. The target is to predict the network throughput of each cell. In this case, the cells are the distributed clients with observations from the local flow records. Meanwhile, the central flow data reflecting the features of several neighboring cells are stored by the central agency as the global feature. Each data sample is a vector composed of features from the flow records. The data features are composed of the typical network parameter settings involving the average user trafic, average and maximum number of active users, small packet ratio, etc. Assisted by the central counterparts, the features among distributed cells form the distributed data sets for FL. The samples in all cells and the central counterparts are divided into a training set and test set. The training loss and the inference test accuracy are recorded in each training mode.

Due to properties of the data features, we employ a multilayer perceptron model (MLP) in the experiments. In distributed cells, the local features are first processed by an MLP model. Then the output feature is concatenated with the globally processed feature and processed by a subsequent MLP model to predict the throughput. At the central agency, a similar MLP model is applied to process the global observations. The results are shared with the local counterparts and concatenated in the local model.

V-B Cloud training benchmark

We shall employ the cloud training on the local and global features of all cells as a basic benchmark. Therein, the cloud training concatenates the local and central models as a whole, following the same structure as VHFL. Meanwhile, we also perform the cloud training by excluding the central feature to validate its effectiveness. The comparison results are shown in Fig. 4, where the cloud training with the combined features obviously outperforming the results based on the local features. This means that the central features are important in this task, which is a typical scenario for VHFL.

V-C VHFL performance

Here, we apply VHFL among the cells and compare the prediction loss with the Horizontal FL and cloud training benchmark. In the HFL mode, the training is only based on the local features where the center only performs model aggregation for distributed cells. Fig. 5(a) shows the training convergence where VHFL could achieve a similar speed as HFL. Meanwhile, with the central feature assistance, the achieved training loss in VHFL is apparently improved. Fig. 5(b) shows the MSE test loss for validation set and Fig. 5(c) shows the corresponding prediction error ratio. As shown in the curves, the model trained by VHFL performs well from a generalization ability. Thus, employing the central feature in FL can significantly improve the model accuracy for applications in the network.

V-D VHFL convergence

As observed in Theorem 1, K𝐾K and Elsubscript𝐸𝑙E_{l} are important parameters for training. Here, we observe the convergence tendency of VHFL with these parameters, as shown in Fig. 6(a) and Fig. 6(b). In Fig. 6(a), the fraction represents KN𝐾𝑁\frac{K}{N}. While K𝐾K is small, increasing K𝐾K could enhance the speed and stability in training. If K𝐾K gets large enough, the effects get smaller. Here we improved the non-i.i.d. data sets by adding a small public set to the distributed cells. If the non-i.i.d. property gets worse, the effects of K𝐾K should be larger. In Fig. 6(b), the convergence speed increases with the local epoch. In this sense, we could increase Elsubscript𝐸𝑙E_{l} in VHFL to reduce the necessary communication rounds. However, the communication gain will get smaller as Elsubscript𝐸𝑙E_{l} keeps increasing. In practice, setting El=20subscript𝐸𝑙20E_{l}=20 may be a good choice.

V-E Delay setting for VHFL implementation

In Section IV, we discussed the delay setting considering the requirement of model collection in VHFL. In practice, since each uploading client and even the message is lost, will consume communication resources, the uploading amount may be restricted. Meanwhile, VHFL will require a certain minimum value of K𝐾K by experience. Thus, the designer needs to control the delay upper-bound Tpsubscript𝑇𝑝T_{p} so that K𝐾K uploaded messages will be received in general. By setting λN=2subscript𝜆𝑁2\lambda_{N}=2, μ1=8subscript𝜇18\mu_{1}=8, and μ2=2subscript𝜇22\mu_{2}=2, we simulate the random network queuing delay as a benchmark. As shown in Fig. 7(a), the theoretical analysis fits well with the experimental results. As α1subscript𝛼1\alpha_{1} gets smaller, the network will become more stressed. Then we may need a much larger Tpsubscript𝑇𝑝T_{p} to achieve the same γ𝛾\gamma. Meanwhile, we set α1=α2=0.5subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼20.5\alpha_{1}=\alpha_{2}=0.5 and change the target γ𝛾\gamma to see the required Tpsubscript𝑇𝑝T_{p}. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the required Tpsubscript𝑇𝑝T_{p} increases exponentionally with the target γ𝛾\gamma. In practice, we could estimate the network conditions and jointly design the system parameters under theoretical guidance.

VI Conclusion

In future 6G communication, the intelligence assisted by distributed learning will be a major engine to assist the IoT applications. From the networking perpestive, how to share the experience while protecting the data security should be an important consideration. The proposal of FL addressed the problem of sharing experience among distributed clients. However, how to combine the central information in distributed training still remains to be solved. For security concern, the global data in the network center can not be directly broadcast. However, if we can utilize such information without direct data transmission, the obtained intelligence will be significantly enhanced.

In this paper, we discussed how to introduce the use of global observations in FL. By combining the training procedure of vertical and horizontal FL, we developed a collaborative training method called Vertical-Horizontal Federated learning (VHFL) where a central agency can train a model to process the global observations. Through theoretical analysis, we developed an analytic bound for the VHFL training loss and showed that the central model will converge with the federal model and achieve a similar convergence rate as conventional HFL. Considering the practical implementation of VHFL, we discussed the effects of network delay and proposed the theoretical principle to schedule the waiting time in model collection. Finally, extensive experimental results were used to validated the effectiveness and convergence of VHFL and were shown to fit well with the theoretical results. In practical network, VHFL can be applied to applications where the global information is effective for distributed intelligent clients.

Appendix B Network analysis
